ans_context_idx: 17
ques: What is the original meaning of the word Norman?
new_context:
The English name "Norman" comes from the French word Norman / normanz, the plural form of Normant, and the modern French Normand. It itself is borrowed from the ancient low French nottmann "Normans", or directly from the ancient Norse Normans, which is Latinized into normannas, normannus, Or nordmanus (Medieval Latin record of the 9th century) means "Vikings".

Proving that any one of these categories is unequal will be a major breakthrough in complexity theory.

ans_context_idx: 1967
ques: The uniflow engine is an attempt to fix an issue that arises in what cycle?
new_context:
Unidirectional flow engine attempts to solve the difficulties caused by the usual countercurrent cycle. In each stroke, the port and cylinder wall will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam, while the hotter inlet steam will waste some energy when restoring the working temperature.

ans_context_idx: 1968
ques: What part is added to the uniflow engine to resolve the issue in the counterflow cycle?
new_context:
The purpose of uniflow is to make up for this defect and improve efficiency by providing an additional port not covered by the piston at the end of each stroke to make the steam flow in only one direction.

ans_context_idx: 2131
ques: What is another term for excessive compression?
new_context:
However, since the same valve usually controls two steam flows, a short cut-off during air intake will have an adverse impact on the exhaust and compression cycle. Ideally, the exhaust and compression cycle should always be fairly constant; If the exhaust time is too short, the whole exhaust steam cannot be discharged from the cylinder, resulting in cylinder blockage and excessive compression ("recoil").

ques: What is a descriptive term for a low-to-high energy bond?
new_context:

ques: What is the most feared condition that divers want to avoid?
new_context:

new_context:

In 1957, competition rules were incorporated into the Treaty of Rome, also known as the EC Treaty, which established the European Economic Community (EEC).

new_context:
Today, Article 101 (1) of the Lisbon treaty prohibits anti competitive agreements, including price manipulation.

ans_context_idx: 3244
ques: What does Article 102 of the Treaty of Lisbon prohibit?
new_context:
Article 102 prohibits abuse of dominance, such as price discrimination and exclusive trading.

new_context:

new_context:
Article 102 allows the Council of Europe to enact regulations governing inter company mergers (the current regulation is regulation 139 / 2004 / EC).

ques: What is the name of the satellite that measured the amount of dust?
new_context:

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 3736
ques: Comb like bands of cilia are called what?
new_context:
Most species have eight bands, called comb rows, arranged along the length of the body, with comb like ciliary bands, called "ctenes", stacked along the comb rows, so that when the cilia beat, the cilia of each comb will contact the comb below.

ques: What are the most active parts of ctenophora?

ans_context_idx: 3763
ques: Combs are called what?
new_context:
"Combs" (also known as "ctenes" or "comb plates") traverse each row, each consisting of thousands of abnormally long cilia up to 2 mm (0.079 in) in length.

ques: What does the 9 +3 pattern of cilia thought to do?
new_context:
Unlike the traditional cilia and flagellum, the traditional cilia and flagellum are arranged in a 9+2 pattern. These cilia are arranged in 9+3 pattern, in which super tight filaments are suspected to have supporting functions.

ans_context_idx: 4265
ques: Packet Switching contrast with what other principal 
new_context:
Packet switching is in contrast to another major network mode, circuit switching, which is a method of pre allocating dedicated network bandwidth for each communication session. Each communication session has a constant bit rate and delay between nodes.

ans_context_idx: 4266
ques: What is circuit switching characterized by
new_context:
In the case of billable services, such as cellular communication services, circuit switching is characterized by the cost per unit of connection time, even if no data is transmitted, while packet switching is characterized by the cost per unit of information transmitted, such as characters, packets or messages.

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 4882
ques: When rock formations are found on top of a fault that have not been cut, then they must be older or younger than the fault?
new_context:
Faults are younger than the rocks they cut; Therefore, if a fault is found to penetrate some strata, but not the strata at the top, the cut stratum is older than the fault, and the uncut stratum must be younger than the fault.

ans_context_idx: 7876
ques: Who thought that the Yuan's social class system shouldn't be called social classes?
new_context:
Historian Frederick W. Mott wrote that the use of the word "social class" in this system is misleading. People's status in the four class system is not a symbol of their actual social power and wealth, but the "degree of privilege" they enjoy in the system and law. Therefore, a person's status in the class cannot guarantee their status, Because the Chinese are rich and have a good social status, while the affluence of Mongols and saimu is lower than that of poor and abused Mongols and saimu.

new_context:
In the stomach, gastric acid and protease are powerful chemical defenses against ingested pathogens.

ans_context_idx: 7985
ques: Vaginal secretions serve as a chemical protective barrier following what?
new_context:
After menarche, vaginal secretions are slightly acidic, which is a chemical barrier, while semen contains defensins and zinc, which can kill pathogens.

ans_context_idx: 7991
ques: What serves as a biological barrier by competing for space and food in the GI tract?
new_context:
In the urogenital and gastrointestinal tract, symbiotic flora acts as a biological barrier by competing with pathogens for food and space and, in some cases, by changing environmental conditions, such as pH or available iron.

ans_context_idx: 7992
ques: Most antibiotics target bacteria and don't affect what class of organisms?
new_context:
However, since most antibiotics are not specific to bacteria and will not affect fungi, oral antibiotics may lead to "overgrowth" of fungi and diseases such as vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection).

new_context:

ques: What is one of the first responses the immune system has to infection?

ans_context_idx: 8001
ques: What causes the symptoms of inflammation?
new_context:

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8003
ques: Eicosanoids include what compounds that result in fever and blood vessel dilation?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8004
ques: What cytokines are responsible for communication between white blood cells?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8010
ques: What type of cells engulf or eat pathogens and foreign particles?
new_context:
Phagocytosis is an important feature of cellular innate immunity, which is performed by "phagocytes" that phagocytize or engulf pathogens or particles.

ans_context_idx: 8011
ques: Phagocytes can be called to a specific location by what?
new_context:
Phagocytes usually patrol the body looking for pathogens, but they can also be called to specific locations by cytokines.

ans_context_idx: 8012
ques: When a pathogen has been eaten by a phagocyte it becomes trapped in what vesicle?
new_context:
Once a pathogen is engulfed by a phagocyte, it is trapped in an intracellular vesicle called a phagosome, which then fuses with another vesicle called a lysosome to form a phagosome.

ans_context_idx: 8013

new_context:
Once a pathogen is engulfed by a phagocyte, it is trapped in an intracellular vesicle called a phagosome, which then fuses with another vesicle called a lysosome to form a phagosome.

ans_context_idx: 8014
ques: Phagocytosis first evolved as means of doing what?
new_context:
Phagocytosis is a means of obtaining nutrition, but this effect has been extended in phagocytes to include phagocytosis of pathogens as a defense mechanism.

ques: How many receptors on a helper T cell must be bound to a MHC:antigen complex in order for the cell to be activated?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8203

ans_context_idx: 8206

ans_context_idx: 8212
ques: Who formulated the idea of clonal selection theory of immunity?
new_context:
In the mid-1950s, Frank Burnett proposed immune clonal selection theory (CST) inspired by Niels Jean's suggestion.

ans_context_idx: 8213
ques: What are two examples of nonself entities in accordance with Frank Burnet's theory?
new_context:
On the basis of CST, Burnett developed a theory on how to trigger immune response according to the difference between self and non self: "self" components (body components) do not trigger destructive immune response, while "non self" entities (pathogens, allografts) trigger destructive immune response.

ans_context_idx: 8214

new_context:
This theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries about histocompatibility or T cell "double signal" activation complexes.

ans_context_idx: 8215

new_context:
In the mid-1950s, Frank Burnett proposed immune clonal selection theory (CST) inspired by Niels Jean's suggestion.

ans_context_idx: 8221
ques: What are the most powerful class of anti-inflammatory drugs?
new_context:
Glucocorticoids are the most effective of these drugs; However, these drugs may have many adverse side effects, such as central obesity, hyperglycemia and osteoporosis, and their use must be strictly controlled.

ans_context_idx: 8222
ques: Low doses of anti-inflammatories are sometimes used with what classes of drugs?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8223

ans_context_idx: 8239

ans_context_idx: 8241
ques: What is the nature of the relationship between T-cells and vitamin D?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8242
ques: What gene is responsible for converting calcidiol into calcitriol?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8249
ques: What are the proteins that organisms use to identify molecules associated with pathogens?

ans_context_idx: 8250
ques: What are the antimicrobial peptides that are the main form of invertebrate systemic immunity called?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8251
ques: What cell type is also used for immune response in most types of invertebrate life?

Complement system and phagocytes are also used by most invertebrates.

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8794
ques: According to Wilson's theorem, what factorial must be divisible by p if some integer p > 1 is to be considered prime?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8835
ques: What is one condition that an element p of R must satisfy in order to be considered a prime element?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 8836

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 11463
ques: What is the resultant force called when two forces act on a particle?
new_context:
When two forces act on a point particle, the resultant force (also known as net force) can be determined by following the parallelogram rule of vector addition: the addition of two vectors represented by the edges of the parallelogram gives an equivalent synthetic vector, whose size and direction are equal to the cross section of the parallelogram.

This formalism includes the pressure term related to the force perpendicular to the cross-sectional area (diagonal of the matrix of tensors) and the shear term related to the force parallel to the cross-sectional area (non diagonal elements).

ans_context_idx: 11684
ques: What is the force equivalent of torque compared to angular momentum?
new_context:
Torque is the rotational equivalent of force, just as angle is the rotational equivalent of position, angular velocity is velocity and angular momentum is momentum.

new_context:

ans_context_idx: 11691
ques: Where does centripetal force go?
new_context:
This means that the unbalanced centripetal force felt by any object always points to the center of the bending path.

ans_context_idx: 11692
ques: How do centripetal forces act in relation to vectors of velocity?
new_context:
The action of these forces is perpendicular to the velocity vector related to the motion of the object, so they will not change the velocity of the object (the magnitude of the velocity), but only change the direction of the velocity vector.

new_context:
This produces tangential and radial (centripetal) forces, the former accelerating an object by decelerating or accelerating it, and the latter changing its direction.

ans_context_idx: 11720
ques: What is the law of thermodynamics associated with closed system heat exchange?
new_context:

ans_context_idx: 11726
ques: What is the metric term less used than the Newton?
new_context:
Pound force has a metric counterpart, which is not as common as Newton: kilogram force (KGF) (sometimes kilopound force), which is the force exerted by standard gravity on a kilogram of mass.

ans_context_idx: 11727

new_context:
Pound force has a metric counterpart, which is not as common as Newton: kilogram force (KGF) (sometimes kilopound force), which is the force exerted by standard gravity on a kilogram of mass.

ans_context_idx: 11728
ques: What is a very seldom used unit of mass in the metric system?
new_context:
Kilogram force leads to another unit of mass, but it is rarely used: the metric unit (sometimes mug or hyl) is the mass accelerated at a speed of 1 m · s − 2 when subjected to a force of 1 KGF.
